etymology.description: 貝(貝) (bèi, "cowry") + 人(人) (rén, "person") = person with a burden -> carrying valuables -> 負(負)
etymology.interpretation: The traditional character 負(負) (fù, "carry on the back") combines 貝(貝) (bèi, "cowry") representing value or burden, and 人(人) (rén, "person") indicating a person bearing this burden. This conveys the action of carrying something valuable, often on the back.
etymology.simplification: Initially, 负(負) shared the same form since they are the same word, so this character doesn't have a simplified form.

examples.chinese: 他负书包(他負書包)，走在去学校的路上(走在去學校的路上)。
examples.pinyin: Tā fù shūbāo, zǒu zài qù xuéxiào de lùshàng.
examples.english: He carries a schoolbag on his back as he walks on the way to school.

examples.chinese: 士兵负盔甲(士兵負盔甲)，驰援前线(馳援前線)。
examples.english: The soldier carries his armor on his back as he rushes to the frontline.

examples.chinese: 登山者负登山包(登山者負登山包)，攀登险峰(攀登險峰)。
examples.english: The climber carries his backpack on his back as he ascends treacherous peaks.
